case_title: KISHANLAL HARICHARAN vs INCOME-TAX OFFICER, A-WARD, NIZAMABAD

accussed_details.name: Kishanlal Haricharan
allegation: Challenge to rectification order under Section 35(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

complaint_summary: Petitioner challenged the rectification order dated March 16, 1965, issued under Section 35(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, alleging it was barred by limitation and void due to procedural irregularities.
investigation_summary: The petitioner was assessed as a Hindu Undivided Family for the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51. Rectification was sought after income from Messrs Sriram Haricharandas, Bombay, was finalized, with the petitioner's share being Rs. 13,00,000. The Commissioner directed reassessment, but the petitioner alleged procedural lapses and limitation issues.
judgment_summary: The court held that the rectification order dated March 16, 1965, was valid and within the limitation period, as the consequential order dated January 29, 1963, constituted the final assessment. The petition was dismissed with costs of Rs. 250.
punishment: Petition dismissed with costs (Advocate's fee Rs. 250).
legal_arguments: Petitioner argued rectification order was barred by limitation under Section 35(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
Respondent justified rectification based on the consequential order dated January 29, 1963.
citations: S. Sangappa v. Income-tax Officer ((1968) 68 ITR 760 (SC))
key_issues: Validity of rectification order under Section 35(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
Notice under Section 35(5) issued after the Income-tax Act, 1961 came into force.

maxims.ex debito justitiae: Mandamus should issue to compel compliance with superior tribunal directions.

legal_terms.rectification: Correction of errors apparent on the record.
legal_terms.limitation: Statutory time limit within which legal action must be taken.

words_and_phrases.consequential order: An order resulting from directions given by a superior authority.

summary_vector_notes: Petitioner challenged rectification order under Section 35(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, alleging procedural lapses and limitation issues. Court upheld validity of rectification order based on consequential order dated January 29, 1963, and dismissed the petition with costs.

petitioner.limitation_period: Four years from the date of the final order under Section 33-A.
petitioner.contention: Impugned order passed beyond the limitation period.

respondent.justification: Rectification order passed within four years from the consequential order dated January 29, 1963.

court_observations.final_order: Income-tax Officer's order dated January 29, 1963 deemed as final order.
